metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: JavaScript Syntax
JavaScript syntax is the set of rules, how JavaScript programs are constructed:
content.html: JavaScript syntax is the set of rules, how JavaScript programs are constructed:

content.code_html:
// How to create variables:
 var x;
let y;

// How to use variables:
 x = 5;
y = 6;
let z = x + y;

content.text: JavaScript Values
The JavaScript syntax defines two types of values:
content.html: The JavaScript syntax defines two types of values:

content.text: Fixed values are called Literals .
content.html: Fixed values are called Literals.

content.text: Variable values are called Variables .
content.html: Variable values are called Variables.

content.text: JavaScript Literals
The two most important syntax rules for fixed values are:
content.html: The two most important syntax rules for fixed values are:

content.text: 1. Numbers are written with or without decimals:
content.html: 1. Numbers are written with or without decimals:

content.code_html:
10.50

1001

content.text: 2. Strings are text, written within double or single quotes:
content.html: 2. Strings are text, written within double or single quotes:

content.code_html:
"John Doe"

'John Doe'

content.text: JavaScript Variables
In a programming language, variables are used to store data values.
content.html: In a programming language, variables are used to store data values.

content.text: JavaScript uses the keywords var , let and const to declare variables.
content.html: JavaScript uses the keywords var, let and const to declare variables.

content.text: An equal sign is used to assign values to variables.
content.html: An equal sign is used to assign values to variables.

content.text: In this example, x is defined as a variable. Then, x is assigned (given) the value 6:
content.html: In this example, x is defined as a variable. Then, x is assigned (given) the value 6:

content.code_html:
let x;
x = 6;

content.text: JavaScript Operators
JavaScript uses arithmetic operators ( + - * / ) to compute values:
content.html: JavaScript uses arithmetic operators ( + - * / ) to compute values:

content.code_html: (5 + 6) * 10

content.text: JavaScript uses an assignment operator ( = ) to assign values to variables:
content.html: JavaScript uses an assignment operator ( = ) to assign values to variables:

content.code_html:
let x, y;
x = 5;
y = 6;

content.text: JavaScript Expressions
An expression is a combination of values, variables, and operators, which computes to a value.
content.html: An expression is a combination of values, variables, and operators, which computes to a value.

content.text: The computation is called an evaluation.
content.html: The computation is called an evaluation.

content.text: For example, 5 * 10 evaluates to 50:
content.html: For example, 5 * 10 evaluates to 50:

content.code_html: 5 * 10

content.text: Expressions can also contain variable values:
content.html: Expressions can also contain variable values:

content.code_html: x * 10

content.text: The values can be of various types, such as numbers and strings.
content.html: The values can be of various types, such as numbers and strings.

content.text: For example, "John" + " " + "Doe", evaluates to "John Doe":
content.html: For example, "John" + " " + "Doe", evaluates to "John Doe":

content.code_html: "John" + " " + "Doe"

content.text: JavaScript Keywords
JavaScript keywords are used to identify actions to be performed.
content.html: JavaScript keywords are used to identify actions to be performed.

content.text: The let keyword tells the browser to create variables:
content.html: The let keyword tells the browser to create variables:

content.code_html:
let x, y;
x = 5 + 6;
y = x * 10;

content.text: The var keyword also tells the browser to create variables:
content.html: The var keyword also tells the browser to create variables:

content.code_html:
var x, y;
x = 5 + 6;
y = x * 10;

content.text: In these examples, using var or let will produce the same result.
content.html: In these examples, using var or let will produce the same result.

content.text: You will learn more about var and let later in this tutorial.
content.html: You will learn more about var and let later in this tutorial.

content.text: JavaScript Comments
Not all JavaScript statements are "executed".
content.html: Not all JavaScript statements are "executed".

content.text: Code after double slashes // or between /* and */ is treated as a comment .
content.html: Code after double slashes // or between /* and */ is treated as a comment.

content.text: Comments are ignored, and will not be executed:
content.html: Comments are ignored, and will not be executed:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let x = 5;   // I will be executed// x = 6;   I will 
NOT be executed

// x = 6;   I will 
NOT be executed

content.code:
let x = 5;   // I will be executed// x = 6;   I will
NOT be executed

syntax_highlighting.text:
let x = 5;   // I will be executed// x = 6;   I will 
NOT be executed

// x = 6;   I will 
NOT be executed

content.code_html:
let x = 5;   // I will be executed

// x = 6;   I will NOT be executed

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let x = 5;   // I will be executed// x = 6;   I will 
NOT be executed

// x = 6;   I will 
NOT be executed

content.text: You will learn more about comments in a later chapter.
content.html: You will learn more about comments in a later chapter.

content.text: JavaScript Identifiers / Names
Identifiers are JavaScript names.
content.html: Identifiers are JavaScript names.

content.text: Identifiers are used to name variables and keywords, and functions.
content.html: Identifiers are used to name variables and keywords, and functions.

content.text: The rules for legal names are the same in most programming languages.
content.html: The rules for legal names are the same in most programming languages.

content.text: A JavaScript name must begin with:
content.html: A JavaScript name must begin with:

content.text: Subsequent characters may be letters, digits, underscores, or dollar signs.
content.html: Subsequent characters may be letters, digits, underscores, or dollar signs.

content.text: Note
Numbers are not allowed as the first character in names.
content.html: Numbers are not allowed as the first character in names.

content.text: This way JavaScript can easily distinguish identifiers from numbers.
content.html: This way JavaScript can easily distinguish identifiers from numbers.

content.text: JavaScript is Case Sensitive
All JavaScript identifiers are case sensitive .
content.html: All JavaScript identifiers are case sensitive.

content.text: The variables lastName and lastname , are two different variables:
content.html: The variables lastName and lastname, are two different variables:

content.code_html:
let lastname, lastName;
lastName = "Doe";
lastname = "Peterson";

content.text: JavaScript does not interpret LET or Let as the keyword let .
content.html: JavaScript does not interpret LET or Let as the keyword let.

content.text: JavaScript and Camel Case
Historically, programmers have used different ways of joining multiple words into one variable name:
content.html: Historically, programmers have used different ways of joining multiple words into one variable name:

content.text: Hyphens:
content.html: Hyphens:

content.text: first-name, last-name, master-card, inter-city.
content.html: first-name, last-name, master-card, inter-city.

content.text: Hyphens are not allowed in JavaScript. They are reserved for subtractions.
content.html: Hyphens are not allowed in JavaScript. They are reserved for subtractions.

content.text: Underscore:
content.html: Underscore:

content.text: first_name, last_name, master_card, inter_city.
content.html: first_name, last_name, master_card, inter_city.

content.text: Upper Camel Case (Pascal Case):
content.html: Upper Camel Case (Pascal Case):

content.text: FirstName, LastName, MasterCard, InterCity.
content.html: FirstName, LastName, MasterCard, InterCity.

content.text: Lower Camel Case:
content.html: Lower Camel Case:

content.text: JavaScript programmers tend to use camel case that starts with a lowercase letter:
content.html: JavaScript programmers tend to use camel case that starts with a lowercase letter:

content.text: firstName, lastName, masterCard, interCity.
content.html: firstName, lastName, masterCard, interCity.

content.text: JavaScript Character Set
JavaScript uses the Unicode character set.
content.html: JavaScript uses the Unicode character set.

content.text: Unicode covers (almost) all the characters, punctuations, and symbols in the world.
content.html: Unicode covers (almost) all the characters, punctuations, and symbols in the world.

content.text: For a closer look, please study our Complete Unicode Reference .
content.html: For a closer look, please study our Complete Unicode Reference.

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
What is a correct syntax for assigning a value to a variable?
content.html: What is a correct syntax for assigning a value to a variable?
